mainmatter.p: In Tom de Jong's thesis and his Agda formalization of domain theory, the term ‚Äústructurally continuous‚Äù is used to mean a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D equipped with a function giving, for every x : D, a small directed family of elements way below x, giving x as its join.
In the new terminology, this notion of ‚Äústructure‚Äù involved in the continuity of a dcpo is made explicit by the following notion.

A continuity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

Factoring this structure out into a definition of its own obviates the need to have a name for the notion of a ‚Äú\mathcal{V}-dcpo having a specified continuity datum‚Äù, which is what ‚Äústructurally continuous‚Äù means. Even though the equivalence between structurally continuous and ‚Äúhaving a specified continuity datum‚Äù is completely trivial, we still record this in the following proposition to be able to explicitly refer to this terminological identity.

frontmatter.meta: Defn 4.4.1 of de Jong's PhD thesis

mainmatter.p: A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D having a specified continuity datum is the same thing as D being structurally continuous.

By replacing the specified existence here with mere existence, we obtain the notion of a continuous \mathcal{V}-dcpo. The terminology for this is unchanged (i.e. is the same as the terminology of Tom de Jong's thesis).
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is called continuous if there exists a continuity datum for it.

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is called pseudocontinuous if there is a specified function giving, for every x : D, the mere existence of a \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo being pseudocontinuous is the same thing as it having a specified continuity datum, but with the specified existence requirement in the notion of continuity datum relaxed to requirement of mere existence.

An intensional continuous basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) with the further requirement that for every x : D, the directed \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) given by the basis satisfies the condition \forall k : K_x. \ \beta ( \kappa _x(k)) \ll x.
An extensional continuous basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional continuous basis that is extensional.

An algebraicity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D that satisfies the following.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) is compact.

Similar to the case of a continuity datum, we record the terminological identity between a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D being ‚Äústructurally algebraic‚Äù (the terminology from de Jong's thesis) and it having a specified algebraicity datum.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D having a specified algebraicity datum is the same thing as D being structurally algebraic.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if there exists an algebraicity datum for it.

Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo and define the type K_x \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{c : D}{ \mathsf{isCompact} ( c ) \times c \sqsubseteq x} of compact elements below a given x : D. The \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if it satisfies the following conditions.
For every x : D, K_x is \mathcal{V}-small.
The \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \mathsf{pr} _1 ) is directed with supremum x.
An intensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) satisfying \forall b : B. \ \mathsf{isCompact} ( \beta (b) ) .
An extensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional algebraic basis (B, \beta ) that is extensional.

frontmatter.title: Summary of order-theoretic terminology in UF

mainmatter.p: In our presentation here, we decouple the notion of a basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo from any kind of compactness or relative compactness requirements.

In the context of domain theory, the natural notion of basis should include such requirements (see for example Defn. 2.2.3 of Abramsky and Jung). As our presentation here is intended to be applicable to a class of lattices broader than that of dcpos, however, we attempt to keep the presentation free of bias towards a specific attitude. This is our motivation for the aforementioned decoupling.

When the notion of a \mathcal{V}-dcpo attains a specific attitude, such as that of a denotational domain, it is perfectly fine for these terms to be overloaded to refer to concepts that include these requirements.

Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo. An intensional basis for D is a \mathcal{V}-family (B, \beta ) on D satisfying the condition: for every element x : D, there is a specified directed \mathcal{V}-family (I_x, \iota _x) on the basis index B such that x = \bigvee (I_x, \beta \circ \iota _x).
Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo. An intensional basis (B, \beta ) for D is called an extensional basis if \beta is an embedding.

In Tom de Jong's thesis and his Agda formalization of domain theory, the term ‚Äústructurally continuous‚Äù is used to mean a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D equipped with a function giving, for every x : D, a small directed family of elements way below x, giving x as its join.
In the new terminology, this notion of ‚Äústructure‚Äù involved in the continuity of a dcpo is made explicit by the following notion.

A continuity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

Factoring this structure out into a definition of its own obviates the need to have a name for the notion of a ‚Äú\mathcal{V}-dcpo having a specified continuity datum‚Äù, which is what ‚Äústructurally continuous‚Äù means. Even though the equivalence between structurally continuous and ‚Äúhaving a specified continuity datum‚Äù is completely trivial, we still record this in the following proposition to be able to explicitly refer to this terminological identity.

frontmatter.meta: Defn 4.4.1 of de Jong's PhD thesis

mainmatter.p: A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D having a specified continuity datum is the same thing as D being structurally continuous.

By replacing the specified existence here with mere existence, we obtain the notion of a continuous \mathcal{V}-dcpo. The terminology for this is unchanged (i.e. is the same as the terminology of Tom de Jong's thesis).
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is called continuous if there exists a continuity datum for it.

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is called pseudocontinuous if there is a specified function giving, for every x : D, the mere existence of a \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo being pseudocontinuous is the same thing as it having a specified continuity datum, but with the specified existence requirement in the notion of continuity datum relaxed to requirement of mere existence.

An intensional continuous basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) with the further requirement that for every x : D, the directed \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) given by the basis satisfies the condition \forall k : K_x. \ \beta ( \kappa _x(k)) \ll x.
An extensional continuous basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional continuous basis that is extensional.

An algebraicity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D that satisfies the following.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) is compact.

Similar to the case of a continuity datum, we record the terminological identity between a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D being ‚Äústructurally algebraic‚Äù (the terminology from de Jong's thesis) and it having a specified algebraicity datum.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D having a specified algebraicity datum is the same thing as D being structurally algebraic.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if there exists an algebraicity datum for it.

Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo and define the type K_x \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{c : D}{ \mathsf{isCompact} ( c ) \times c \sqsubseteq x} of compact elements below a given x : D. The \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if it satisfies the following conditions.
For every x : D, K_x is \mathcal{V}-small.
The \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \mathsf{pr} _1 ) is directed with supremum x.
An intensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) satisfying \forall b : B. \ \mathsf{isCompact} ( \beta (b) ) .
An extensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional algebraic basis (B, \beta ) that is extensional.

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale X is called spectral if it satisfies the following three conditions.
It is a compact locale (i.e. the empty meet is compact).
The meet of two compact opens is compact.
For every U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of compact opens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf{isCompact} ( \kappa _{U}(k) ).

Notice the relationship of the third condition here to pseudocontinuity. If we formulate a notion of ‚Äúpseudoalgebraicity‚Äù i.e. the analogue of pseudocontinuity for algebraicity, we could use that to avoid the repetition here because they are exactly the same thing. This is not good for presentation purposes (as for as locale theory is concerned), however, so it should probably be recorded as an equivalence.

frontmatter.title: Intensional spectral basis for a locale

mainmatter.p:
An intensional spectral basis for a \mathcal{W}-locale X is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) for the frame \mathcal{O} ( X ) (considered as a \mathcal{W}-dcpo) that satisfies the following two conditions
For every b : B, \beta (b) is a compact open of X.
The basis (B, \beta ) is closed under finite meets. This is to say that it satisfies the following conditions.
It contains the empty meet: \exists t : B. \ \mathsf{isTop} ( \beta (t)).
It is closed under binary meets: \forall b_1, b_2 : B. \ \exists b_3 : B \ \beta (b_3) \ \text{is the glb of} \ \{ \beta (b_2), \beta (b_3) \} .

frontmatter.title: Extensional spectral basis for a locale

mainmatter.p: An extensional spectral basis (B, \beta ) for a \mathcal{W}-locale is an intensional spectral basis that is extensional.

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale X is called zero-dimensional if it satisfies the following condition: for every U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of clopens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf{isClopen} ( \kappa _{U}(k)).

An algebraicity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D that satisfies the following.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) is compact.

A continuity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is called continuous if there exists a continuity datum for it.

tree.mainmatter: This tree is unintentionally left blank.

mainmatter.p: Let \mathcal{V} be a universe. A poset D is a \mathcal{V}-dcpo if the join of of every \mathcal{V}-family on set D exists in D.

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called structurally algebraic if for every x : D we have a specified I : \mathcal{V} and directed compact family \kappa : I \to D such that \kappa has supremum x and each element \kappa (i) is compact.
Definition 4.6.1 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis.

frontmatter.title: Domain theory in constructive and predicative univalent foundations
frontmatter.meta: @phdthesis{tdj-thesis, title = {Domain theory in constructive and predicative univalent foundations}, author = {de Jong, Tom}, date = {2023}, school = {University of Birmingham}, location = {Birmingham, UK}, uri = {http://etheses.bham.ac.uk/id/eprint/13401}, }
